questions.question: If the target minimum received power is -80 dBm, and the received power at a distance d is -75 dBm, what is the outage probability at this distance?

explanations.a: Incorrect – outage probability cannot be 1 if signal is above threshold.
explanations.b: Correct – received power (-75 dBm) is above -80 dBm threshold, so no outage occurs.
explanations.c: Incorrect – 0.75 is not applicable in this case.

questions.question: A receiver at distance d = 1 km experiences a pathloss of 80 dB. If the transmitter power is 35 dBm and the target minimum power is -45 dBm, does this receiver experience an outage?

explanations.a: Correct – received power is 35 - 80 = -45 dBm, exactly at the threshold, so it is considered outage in strict threshold definitions.
explanations.b: Incorrect – the signal is at the limit, meaning marginal coverage or outage.
explanations.c: Incorrect – this can be determined with given values.
explanations.d: Incorrect – all needed parameters are provided.

questions.question: If the coverage radius of a base station is increased while keeping transmit power constant, what is likely to happen to the outage probability?

explanations.a: Correct – larger coverage radius means more users at edge with weak signal, increasing outage.
explanations.b: Incorrect – this happens only with more transmit power or better antennas.
explanations.c: Incorrect – pathloss changes with distance, so outage changes too.

questions.question: A cell has an outage probability of 0.1. Which statement is correct?

answers.a: 10% of locations in the cell have unacceptable signal levels
answers.c: Only 10 users can connect at a time

explanations.a: Correct – outage probability 0.1 means 10% of locations fall below threshold.
explanations.b: Incorrect – outage probability says nothing about transmitter count.
explanations.c: Incorrect – this relates to capacity, not outage probability.
explanations.d: Incorrect – 90% have coverage, not zero coverage.

questions.question: Which technique can help improve coverage without increasing transmit power?

explanations.a: Correct – higher gain antennas focus energy and improve received power.
explanations.b: Incorrect – reducing height usually reduces coverage.
explanations.d: Incorrect – higher noise figure reduces performance.

questions.question: If the received SNR is below the target SNR threshold, this results in:

explanations.a: Incorrect – low SNR does not expand coverage.
explanations.b: Correct – if SNR < threshold, the link is considered in outage.
explanations.c: Incorrect – low SNR means worse quality.
explanations.d: Incorrect – SNR is not the same as pathloss.

questions.question: In a Rayleigh fading channel, outage probability is typically:

explanations.a: Correct – multipath fading causes deeper fades, increasing outage probability.
explanations.c: Incorrect – fading always causes some probability of outage.
explanations.d: Incorrect – fading is directly related to outage.

questions.question: Which environment would likely require the smallest cell radius to maintain low outage probability?

explanations.a: Correct – buildings and obstructions cause high pathloss, requiring smaller cells.
explanations.b: Incorrect – rural areas can have large coverage due to fewer obstructions.
explanations.c: Incorrect – suburban has moderate coverage needs.
explanations.d: Incorrect – over-water paths generally have low pathloss.
